entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies series: Don't fly blind (Stress to strength: Mindful living in work & beyond)
entry.content:
Thanks to Moshe

First of all, a heartfelt thank you to  @moshenaveh , who initiated this wonderful blog series about hobbies in the SAP Community. His post ‚ÄúMind your step‚Äù about walking and hiking not only inspired me, but also showed me how closely movement, nature, and inner peace are connected. Hiking and running have also been passions of mine for many years. But one special experience led me onto a new path: the path of yoga. Today I combine both movement in nature and on the yoga mat, combined with mindfulness, conscious breathing, and inner clarity.

Me on a mindful hike near Austria wearing a hat.

Who I am

My name is Achim Toeper, and I have been part of the SAP world for more than three decades. My professional journey has taken me deep into technology and leadership ‚Äì but at the same time I discovered another passion: yoga and mindfulness. Since completing my yoga teacher training in 2018, these practices have become an integral part of my life. They give me energy, inspiration, and a new way of engaging with people in projects, teams, and communities. From this connection, personal projects where born, in which I combine movement, mindfulness, and leadership skills, like writing and talking about it.

My path to yoga

Some years ago, I found myself in an extremely intense professional period, marked by great responsibility and pressure. The stress kept growing ‚Äì and I realized that I needed a counterbalance to avoid burning out. In this search, I came across yoga for the first time in a wellness hotel in the Allg√§u ‚Äì at exactly the moment when I needed it the most. This experience truly flashed me: I immediately felt that yoga is more than just movement. During those very days, I knew I wanted to dive deeper and one day become a yoga teacher myself. Step by step I learned how to regain strength through conscious breathing, movement, and meditation. Yoga gave me not only calm and balance, but also a new perspective on leadership, collaboration, and on myself.

Yoga class and ice bathing in the Ore Mountains 2014

A special moment in Copenhagen

Since that first encounter, yoga has become a constant part of my life. In 2018 I had the opportunity to bring my passion into a very special setting at the SAP Community Event in Copenhagen. At the end of my talk, I sat down cross-legged on stage while the audience remained in their seats. Behind me, an animated GIF was running in my presentation, visualizing the rhythm of box breathing:
inhale for four seconds, hold for four seconds, exhale for four seconds, hold for four seconds.
Together we followed this rhythm ‚Äì and for a moment the large conference room became completely silent. Everyone was connected through the same breathing pattern. This experience was surprising for many and deeply moving for me: a moment where technology, community, and mindfulness came together in a very powerful way. 



A special honor for me on World Mental Health Day

Another highlight was October 10th 2023, the international World Mental Health Day. On this day, I was invited to lead an international yoga session for my company. People from different countries and time zones came together virtually to breathe, move, and pause for a moment. For me it was a great honor and at the same time a confirmation that mindfulness and yoga go far beyond private practice ‚Äì they can build bridges, create community, and have a tangible impact in a global professional environment.

What yoga means to me

For me, yoga is far more than physical exercises. It is an attitude that shapes everyday life ‚Äì both professionally and personally. It reminds me that behind every role and function there is always a human being. This perspective has changed my leadership style: away from pure control, towards more trust, calmness, and leading by example. In my company, some colleagues jokingly call me ‚ÄúYoda‚Äù ‚Äì a nice sign that mindfulness not only brings calm but also inspiration. For me, yoga is a compass that helps me stay clear, human, and connected even in challenging situations.

Practicing Vrksasana Yoga ‚ÄúTree Pose‚Äù on a hike.

Running, swimming, and the strength of connecting with others

Back in 2000, I joined a group mainly consisting of triathletes and hockey players. That was the moment I finally started running ‚Äì something I had enjoyed before but never really practiced regularly.
My last major run was in 2014 in Vienna, a city that holds a special place in my heart.

Last year ‚Äì as well as this year ‚Äì I completed an Olympic triathlon. Swimming has always had a calming effect on me, running grounds me in the here and now, and the combination of all three disciplines teaches me perseverance, humility, and trust in my own body.

I remember well the SAP Community Event in Copenhagen in May 2018 ‚Äì that‚Äôs where I met @smarchesini .
Sebastiano is not only someone who drives SAP topics forward, but also someone who shares his passion for running with others.
I am delighted that he will be next in this hobbies series ‚Äì because running connects us, and I am sure his story will bring fresh inspiration.

Photo of me taken during a race at a multi-generational run

Join the conversation

Do you do Yoga or Meditation? Share the pictures and stories behind them in the comments section. Feel free to share other hobbies you have!

If you're interested in joining the series, please reach out to Moshe Naveh via community@sap.com.

Let's get this journey going! I hope you all enjoy the great posts coming-up!

entry.title: Re: Dive into the future of SAP Universal ID and understand the changes underway
entry.content:
Dear Community Members,

Thank you for sharing your feedback and concerns with us.

The primary change is that SAP Universal ID will no longer function as an identity provider. This modification to the login process is a crucial component of a broader initiative aimed at streamlining user management. It also serves as a technical foundation that will eventually allow customers to integrate their own corporate identity providers seamlessly.

Other substantial features of SAP Universal ID will stay: Your SAP Universal ID continues to serve as a wallet for managing your user identities. It ensures lifelong access to your account and preserves your reputation such as learning certificates and community content.

We apologize for the temporary inconvenience caused by the need to manage multiple user identities and manually switch between them due to the recent changes. SAP is currently developing an account switcher functionality to alleviate this issue.

Once the new functionality is implemented, you will log in using your S/P-user or the associated email address. After logging in, the system will display all user identities (S/P-users) linked to your UID. You can then switch to another user identity by clicking on it and entering the associated password.

For more information about future developments in authentication for digital platforms, you can refer to this News Article and YouTube interview.

To bring up improvement requests directly, join our SAP Continuous Influence session to share detailed ideas and requirements on bring your own identity, S-user management, and SAP Universal ID, ensuring clarity and effective review by SAP (an S-user is required to submit improvement requests).

entry.title: Re: How to consume APIs in custom RAP application for SAP...
entry.content:
Hello,
Thank you very much for your question. Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) answers your questions:

To consume an external API in a RAP application within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud environment, follow these steps:

  1. Identify the External API: Determine the API you need to consume and understand its specifications, including endpoints, authentication methods, and data formats.

  2. Create a Communication Scenario: Set up a communication scenario in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Creating Custom APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public ‚Ä¶ - SAP Community Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community to enable external communication. This involves defining the API endpoints and authentication details.

  3. Develop the RAP Application:

    • Define the Data Model: Use Core Data Services (CDS) to define the data model that will interact with the external API.
    • Implement Business Logic: Create ABAP classes to handle the API requests and responses. Use ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in Eclipse to write the necessary code.
    • Expose as OData Service: Define a service definition and service binding to expose the data model as an OData service.

  4. Test the Integration: Use tools like Postman to test the API integration and ensure that the RAP application correctly consumes and processes the external API data.

Best Practices and Configurations

  • Security: Ensure secure communication by using HTTPS and appropriate authentication methods like OAuth.
  • Error Handling: Implement robust error handling in your ABAP classes to manage API failures gracefully.
  • Performance Optimization: Optimize API calls to reduce latency and improve the application‚Äôs performance.

Sample Code Snippet

Here is a basic example of how you might structure the ABAP code to consume an external API:

CLASS zcl_external_api_handler DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_http_service_extension .

  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
    DATA: lt_response TYPE string.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zcl_external_api_handler IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD if_http_service_extension~handle_request.
    DATA(lv_req_body) = request->get_text( ).
    " Call external API and process response
    CALL METHOD me->consume_external_api
      EXPORTING
        iv_request_body = lv_req_body
      IMPORTING
        ev_response_body = lt_response.
    response->set_text( lt_response ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD consume_external_api.
    " Implement API consumption logic here
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Additional Resources

For more detailed guidance, you can refer to the SAP Extensibility Explorer for examples and tutorials on different types of extensibility available in S/4HANA Cloud.

[1] Creating Custom APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public ... - SAP Community
[2] Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: #CoE#OTMC Zscaler and SAP Router
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content.) is useful.

Migrating SAP Router to an Azure Virtual Machine protected by Zscaler involves several considerations, especially regarding the compatibility of SAP‚Äôs private protocols with Zscaler‚Äôs Zero-Trust policies.

Key Considerations:

  1. SAP Router Functionality:

    • SAP Router is a crucial component for managing remote connections between SAP systems and clients like SAPGUI. It uses proprietary protocols for authentication and communication.

  2. Zscaler Integration:

    • Zscaler provides a cloud-based security platform that enforces Zero-Trust policies, which might affect how SAP Router communicates with SAPGUI.
    • Zscaler Private Access (ZPA) can potentially replace SAP Router by providing secure access to internal applications without the need for a VPN.

  3. Compatibility and Configuration:

    • Ensure that Zscaler‚Äôs policies allow the necessary SAP protocols to pass through without interference.
    • You may need to configure Zscaler to recognize and allow SAP Router‚Äôs traffic, ensuring that authentication and data integrity are maintained.

  4. Testing and Validation:

    • Conduct thorough testing to ensure that SAPGUI can still connect seamlessly through SAP Router when protected by Zscaler.
    • Validate that all security policies are correctly applied and do not disrupt SAP Router‚Äôs functionality.

Recommendations:

  • Consult with SAP and Zscaler Support: Engage with both SAP and Zscaler support teams to understand the best practices for integrating SAP Router with Zscaler.
  • Pilot Testing: Before full migration, conduct pilot tests to identify any potential issues and ensure smooth operation.
  • Documentation and Training: Ensure that your technical team is well-informed about the changes and trained on managing the new setup.

While there is limited information available online about this specific integration, these steps should help guide you through the process. If you have further questions, consulting with experts who have experience in SAP and Zscaler integration might be beneficial.

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: Does SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Support OCR-based Invoi...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Supplier Invoice Processing, Overview of SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management & Invoice List Partner for more details.

In summary, there is currently no built-in OCR capability to scan and capture supplier invoices from PDF or paper format directly into the system in the public cloud. Standard supplier invoice processing is available in the Fiori apps (such as Create Supplier Invoice, Create Supplier Invoice- Advanced), and electronic invoice can be integrated through APIs and interfaces.

If you require OCR invoice capture, the recommended approach from SAP is for you to use SAP central Invoice Management which integrates with SAP Business Network. This solution provides scanning, OCR machine learning-based extraction of invoice data. Please note that this requires additional licensing.

Alternatively, you can integrate a third-party OCR solution from SAP Store. This will enable you feed invoice data into the public cloud through SAP Integration Suite.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Understanding the importance of legacy bonus plan eligibility rules in Variable Pay
entry.content:
Introdution

In this blog we look at the importance of legacy bonus plan eligibility rules in Variable Pay. We can turn them on with the following checkboxes:

 

They are the only ones that will work both for EC records and Imported (non-EC) records (EC bonus plan rules only work for EC imported records) and as such are critical to handle the following scenarios:

  • Case of permanently transferred employees (for example 1/1 to 3/31 employee of the Peru legal entity then 4/1 to 9/1 employee of the Canada legal entity and since 9/2 employee of the US legal entity) where customer needs to export the data for the different userID retrieved from EC and load it under the ID of the latest active record in order for the full payout to show up on the statement of the most current active record of the employee.
  • Case of EC data missing for the first cycle (for example bonus cycle is 1/1 to 12/31 and EC data cutover was 9/1 so two third of the fiscal year data of reference is missing in EC and needs to be imported in the VarPay template's Employee History.

What is supported and not supported in legacy rules based on the few information I was able to gather and most importantly based on my own testing in my demo environment:

  • SUPPORTED : OR conditions
  • SUPPORTED : OR + AND conditions
  • NOT SUPPORTED : > or < conditions on decimal fields

 

How to handle simple OR conditions in legacy bonus plan rules

 

How to handle complex OR + AND conditions in legacy bonus plan rules

 

How to handle more complex cases ? 

Turn on the following setting in Plan Setup :

Then navigate to Configure Business Rules and chose the following:

 

Save the rule (you might need to navigate to Manage Business Configuration > Employee Profile > Background Element > click Details on the field you want to use to know their unique ID such as ffld2 or vfld4)  then map it to your Bonus Plan :

 

 

 

 

 

All the best,
Xavier

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C): Generated E-Mail footer
entry.content:
Hello Aneu61,

Firstly you will need to create a branding template which is a simple HTML file with a #TEXT# placeholder.  Upload this to the Templates store within C4C.

This template needs to be associated to the Outbound email channel.  Go to Administrator > Service and Social > E-Mail Addresses (under Communication Channels) > Select your Outbound email channel and Edit.

Scroll down until you see the option 'Template'.  Using the search option within this field locate the template you generated.  Save and Test.

This article contains some good information as to e-mail channels in C4C.

https://community.sap.com/t5/crm-and-cx-blog-posts-by-sap/email-response-management-in-c4c-part-2-cloud-for-service-expert-corner/ba-p/13226122

Hope that helps, Andrew

entry.title: Automating Custom Performance Data Transfer to Employee Profiles
entry.content:
Automating Custom Performance Data Transfer to Employee Profiles

At SAP SuccessFactors, dynamic employee profile is the heart of a successful Human Experience Management (HXM) strategy.  If your client wants to transfer critical information from Performance Form to Employee Profile through seamless user interface, this is possible.

Performance Form

Consider a scenario within SuccessFactors, a manager completes a Performance Management Form, that includes custom section ‚Äì with Field 1, Field 2, Field 3.  This data needs to be pushed to Employee Profile ‚Äì Background element.

Employee profile

The Employee Profile in SAP SuccessFactors is a centralized repository that captures employee skills, experiences, education, and career preferences, supporting talent management, succession planning, and development initiatives across organization.

Here, we have a Background element configured that includes Field 1, Field 2, Field 3.

Screenshot added below for reference.

  

Technical Diagram

The technical diagram below illustrates the integration flow built using SAP BTP Integration Suite to enable data exchange between Performance Form custom fields and the Employee Profile background element. It outlines the key steps involved, including API calls, data transformation, and posting using OData APIs. This setup leverages cloud integration capabilities to ensure smooth and automated data transfer between the two SuccessFactors modules.

 Technical specifications

Leveraging the Cloud Integration capability of Integration Suite service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) you can easily connect various data elements to exchange data. We will be doing the same over here to exchange data between Performance Form custom fields and Employee Profile ‚Äì background element. In the process we will be using the below listed APIs and entities ‚Äì

  1. URL of background element API- SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  2. API type ‚Äì ODATA
  3. Authentication - Basic
  4. Entity ‚Äì EPCustomBackgroundPortlet
  5. Endpoint ‚Äì /EPCustomBackgroundPortlet
  6. Method ‚Äì POST

 

  1. URL of performance form API ‚Äì SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  2. API type ‚Äì ODATA
  3. Authentication - Basic
  4. Entity ‚Äì FormCustomSection
  5. Endpoint- /FormCustomSection
  6. Method - GET

Process

 

Below listed are the steps that you need to follow to attain the objective-

  • Step 0: Login to Integration Suite and create an I-flow.
  • Step 1- GET Data: Create a GET call to retrieve data from the performance form using the above listed API. Various filters and select queries can also be used while retrieving the data. (/FormCustomSection).

  • Step 2- Content modifier: Store the data in content modifier.

  • Step 3 ‚Äì JSON to XML converter: Convert the JSON payload to XML
  • Step 4 ‚Äì Filter: Filter the XML payload for the fields which are required to be passed to employee profile

  • Step 5 ‚Äì XML to JSON converter: Convert the filtered payload back to JSON
  • Step 6 ‚Äì Content modifier: Store the filtered payload
  • Step 7 ‚Äì POST data: Post the data to employee profile form using the above listed API  (/EPCustomBackgroundPortlet)

Conclusion:
Automating the transfer of custom performance data to employee profiles in SAP SuccessFactors enhances data accuracy and streamlines talent management. By leveraging SAP BTP‚Äôs Integration Suite and OData APIs, organizations can ensure seamless, efficient, and scalable synchronization between performance forms and employee profile.

Thankyou!

entry.title: ENGINEERING CHANGE MANAGEMENT(ECM)
entry.content:
Engineering change Management(ECM):

ECM  is used to keep track of changes to master data and also control those changes to master data, so that only those with authorisation can make the change. we can maintain history with all the changes done with respect to change number.

STEPS FOR CREATION AND USING ECM:

  go to cc01 transaction code and click on enter as it ECN is internal number here

Cc01

 

Enter description ,valid date and change number status should be active(01)

         

next click on object types and new screen will open here we can select which master data we want to keep track on ,select BOM, Task list by selecting the  first three tick marks

 

now click on save

ECN number 500000000000 got created now if you make any changes to BOM or routing pass the ECN number or make ECN  manadatory for changes to BOM and routing

 

to test the changes 

now go to CA02 and pass ECN also with material details

 

 

there is no description for operation i am adding it and saving it

 

to check the changes made go to cc02 and pass the ECN number

 

then go to environment and then to reporting and then to tasklist

 

now we can see the history of all master data changes made with this particular ECN

 

CONCLUSION: Engineering change management helps us to track the changes made to Master data(BOM, Routing etc),Which helps in accountability and identifying changes done to that particular data. we can even restrict the users from doing changes and allow only authorized people to make changes to that particular data.

entry.title: Re: managing Pallets in S4 hana public cloud
entry.content:
Good day @FaisalMaayeh 

Thank you for your question to the community.

Have a look at Handling Units in Cloud Processes & Batch Management for more details.

In summary, you are correct that the Serial Number app in the SH4C is intended for serialised products and not for pallets. If your requirement is to tract supplier assigned pallet IDs and their storage bins, then you should consider a few approaches:

  1. If EWM is in scope, handling units will come serve the purpose. Here you can model each pallet as handling unit, assign the supplier serial number to the HU (either as HU external ID or as an HU characteristic) and then you manage bin assignments through warehouse tasks.
  2. If your HU management is not activated, you could use Batch Management. Please note, if you create a characteristic for Supplier Pallet Serial Number, you can record pallet Ids during goods receipt and track them at batch level.  Handling Units in Cloud Processes
  3. Finally, you can alternatively use Custom Fields and Logic to extend goods receipt document with a custom field for pallet serial number. This will you to capture the supplier‚Äôs ID without changing standard material serialisation. Custom Fields and Custom Business Logic

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP MDG-M Custom UI Configuration Performance Comparison and Gains
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP MDG-M, the standard User Interface (UI) is designed to load the full set of content, ensuring complete visibility but often at the cost of speed and responsiveness. While this ‚Äúload-everything‚Äù approach guarantees access to all data, it also introduces performance bottlenecks that slow down day-to-day work. 

As a team, we explored ways to mitigate these performance challenges and developed a Custom UI solution tailored to our specific needs. But how much of a difference does this new UI make?

To answer this, we conducted structured performance tests, analyzing key factors such as page load times, system resource utilization, and user feedback. This study will reveal the concrete benefits of the new Custom UI compared to standard UIs, providing insights for future optimization efforts.

Background

A good user experience is a key requirement for any user-centric application. As SAP MDG is an enterprise solution involving hundreds of fields per domain, it‚Äôs very important to display the relevant role-specific information at each governance process step in a user-friendly manner. This will help the data stewards and data analysts make smart decisions with the help of simple and responsive UIs. 

Standard UIs provide a solid foundation for these processes, ensuring consistency and reliability across the system. As data volumes and usage scenarios expand, however, opportunities emerge to further optimize performance.

User feedback and technical performance analyses highlighted areas where the standard UIs could be further optimized ‚Äî particularly around load times, resource usage, and navigation flow. To address these opportunities, our team designed a Custom UI solution focused on boosting performance and enhancing usability, while still building on the strengths of the existing framework. 

In this study, we assess the impact of Custom UIs on performance and compare them with existing standard UIs. The goal is to determine the areas where improvements have been achieved.

Test Methodology and Scope

To measure these differences objectively, we conducted rigorous performance tests under identical conditions.

For performance analysis, we focused on the following criteria:
  • Page Load Time: A crucial factor affecting user experience
  • System Resource Utilization: Efficiency in memory (RAM), CPU, and database queries
  • User Feedback: Objective evaluation through surveys and scores

Tests were conducted under predefined conditions using identical datasets. Below are the tools and test conditions used.

Testing Tool:  Http Trace Using

UI Type: Standard UI (BS_MAT_OVP_09H) - Average Load Time: 1789 msn


Figure 1 ‚Äì Standard UI http trace

UI Type: Custom UI (Z9H_BS_MAT_OVP_09H) - Average Load Time: 858 msn


Figure 2 ‚Äì Custom UI http trace

System Resource Utilization (Memory, CPU, Database Queries)

UI Type: Standart UI - AT_OVP~BS_MAT_OVP_09


Figure 3 ‚Äì Standard UI System Resource Utilization

UI Type: Custom UI - P~Z9H_BS_MAT_OVP_09H


Figure 4 ‚Äì Custom UI System Resource Utilization

The performance metrics above may vary depending on several factors such as the density of data in the database, system resource usage, network speed, and similar elements. Therefore, performance results may differ under varying conditions.

Results and Gains

Our analysis revealed clear benefits that directly strengthen both system efficiency and the user experience. The enhancements not only streamline resource usage but also make the UI more responsive and enjoyable to work with ‚Äî especially in large-scale data operations

Here‚Äôs a summary of the key gains achieved with the Custom UI:
  • Performance Improvement: Noticeably faster page load times, ensuring smoother workflows.
  • Optimized Resource Utilization: Reduced memory and CPU usage, allowing the system to run more efficiently.
  • Higher User Satisfaction: Improved usability and more positive user feedback, reflecting greater engagement.

Thank you for reading,

Best regards.

Ahmet

entry.title: Re: Same short desc & Long desc for different material co...
entry.content:
To your question "Does same short/long description = duplicate material?", not necessarily. In SAP, the material number (MATNR) is the true unique identifier. Descriptions (short/long) are just text fields and can be reused across multiple materials. Generic descriptions like ‚ÄúBolt‚Äù or ‚ÄúCable‚Äù are often reused for different sizes/specs. Different plants or business units may create materials with the same description but different control data (valuation class, base unit, procurement type, etc.).

When you can consider that as a duplication is If all key attributes (material group, base unit, valuation class, procurement type, etc.) are the same, and only the material number differs, then yes‚Äîit‚Äôs likely a duplicate. Duplicates often arise when materials are created via multiple channels (MM01 manually vs. Data Services migration) without a harmonized governance process.

So if you ask me how to check the duplicates, perform the below steps


Go to MARA/MARC tables. Compare fields like MATKL (Material Group), MEINS (Base Unit), MTART (Material Type), BKLAS (Valuation Class). If many fields match along with identical descriptions, it‚Äôs a strong duplicate candidate.

Use ‚ÄúOld Material Number‚Äù (MARA-BISMT) if available ‚Üí Sometimes legacy codes are stored here and can help identify duplicates.

entry.title: Choosing the Right SAP Analytics Tool: Features, Benefits, and Strategy
entry.content:
Introduction : 

Within an organization's data and analytics strategy, SAP provides a portfolio of analytics solutions, including SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), each with a specific function. To assist clients in selecting the best option for their requirements, a comparative analysis of their salient characteristics and advantages is provided below.

SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics

Summary: This solution, which is directly integrated into the SAP S/4HANA ERP system, offers real-time analytics on operational data without requiring data replication.

Key Benefits :

  • Operational Reporting in Real Time: Get the most recent information straight from the ERP system.
  • Views of Core Data Services (CDS): For customizable reporting, use virtual data models.
  • Predefined KPIs and Dashboards: Use unconventional content to gain rapid insights.
  • Fiori-Based User Interface: Enhanced user experience through intuitive design.

Benefits:

  • Immediate Decision-Making: Facilitates quick actions based on current data.
  • Simplified Infrastructure: Eliminates the need for separate data warehousing solutions.
  • Seamless Integration: Embedded within the core ERP system, ensuring consistency.

 

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

Summary: A cloud-based platform combining business intelligence, planning, and predictive analytics, SAC connects to various data sources, including SAP and non-SAP systems.

Key Features:

  • Advanced Analytics: Utilize AI-driven insights and predictive modelling.
  • Planning Capabilities: Integrate financial planning and budgeting processes.
  • Collaboration Tools: Facilitate real-time discussions and decision-making.
  • Mobile Accessibility: Access analytics on-the-go through optimized dashboards.

Benefits:

  • Comprehensive Insights: Consolidates data from multiple sources for holistic analysis.
  • Enhanced Forecasting: Improves accuracy in planning and budgeting.
  • Scalability: Cloud infrastructure supports growth and flexibility.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)

 Overview: A fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, enabling advanced analytics and AI-driven insights across the organization.

Key Features:

  • Data Integration: Connects disparate data sources into a unified platform.
  • AI and ML Capabilities: Leverages machine learning for predictive analytics.
  • Prebuilt Applications: Offers industry-specific solutions and dashboards.
  • Data Governance: Ensures data quality and compliance across the organization.

Benefits:

  • Accelerated Decision-Making: Provides timely insights for informed decisions.
  • Reduced Complexity: Simplifies data management and analytics processes.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: Fosters cross-departmental data sharing and insights.

 

Comparative Study

Recommendation:

  • Choose SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics if your primary need is real-time, operational reporting directly within your ERP system, with minimal infrastructure overhead.

  • Opt for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) when you require advanced analytics, predictive modeling, and planning capabilities across various data sources, with a focus on scalability and collaboration.

  • Consider SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) if your organization seeks a unified platform for data integration, governance, and AI-driven insights, encompassing both SAP and third-party data sources.

Thank you for your time.  Stay connected for further updates on Analytics !

-With Warm Regards :  GIRI

entry.title: Re: Set the batch number to a fixed value for each materi...
entry.content:
Hi Freya,

Based your description, I suggest that you can leverage several BAdIs to meet your requirement.

First is LOBM_AFTER_BATCH_NUMBER_INT, you can use this BAdI to create a new batch number and adapt it. But the limitation is that it only works when the batch number doesn't exist. So you can implement some logics to check if in I_BATCH, the batch number exists. If exists, you need to use BAdI MMIM_GR4XY_PROVIDE_DATA and MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA. These BAdIs can help you to change data in goods receipt and material documents. So they can work in the APP MIGO and Post Goods Receipt. You can implement some logics to change the relevant fields' value.

Hope my answer can help you to solve the question.

Best Regards,

Zhehui

entry.title: ABAP's Parallel Processing Frameworks: Practical Guide to Performance Tuning of Mass Data Processing
entry.content:
While working on a project to optimize a standard SAP report that struggled with large data volumes, I took a deep dive into performance tuning in ABAP, specifically focusing on parallel processing. This journey led me to a comprehensive analysis of the various methods SAP provides for running processes in parallel.

I discovered that parallel processing in ABAP is achieved using one of two core technologies. The first is the Remote Function Call (RFC), where both asynchronous (aRFC) and background (bgRFC) variants can be used to run tasks in parallel. The second technology is based on  background processes. To make implementation easier, several frameworks have been built on top of these technologies, simplifying the development process.

This blog post is a summary of the theoretical research I conducted for my bachelor's thesis. Its goal is to provide a comprehensive overview of the different technologies and the six key frameworks I identified. Think of it as a practical guide to help you choose the most suitable framework for your needs, with linked resources for anyone who wants to dive deeper into a specific topic.

The Landscape of Parallel Processing in ABAP

As mentioned in the introduction, parallel processing in ABAP is based on two core technologies. To simplify their use, multible frameworks have been developed for easier implementation. The following table provides an overview of these technologies and their corresponding frameworks:

Now, let's explore how each of these core technologies enables parallel processing.

Asynchronous Remote Function Call (aRFC)

The Asynchronous Remote Function Call is one of the older and established SAP technology for parallel processing in ABAP. It works by starting a session in a separate dialog work process, which then executes a function module in parallel with the main program. The calling program does not wait for the function to finish and continues its own processing immediately.

By starting multiple aRFCs in a row, you can achieve a significant parallelization effect, as each call runs simultaneously in its own process. This is implemented using the STARTING NEW TASK addition to the standard CALL FUNCTION statement. A example call could look like this:

CALL FUNCTION '<function_module_name>'
STARTING NEW TASK '<task_name>'
DESTINATION IN GROUP <server_group>
PERFORMING <callback_form> ON END OF TASK.

For a more detailed guide on aRFCs, check out these resources:

  • Book: Gahm, H. (2009): ABAP Performance Tuning
  • Jolfaei, M. A. and Neuwirt, E. (2006): Master the five remote function call (RFC) types in ABAP
  • SAP Help Portal: Asynchronous RFC (aRFC)
  • SAP Help Portal: Parallel Processing with Asynchronous RFC

 

Background Remote Function Call (bgRFC)

The Background Remote Function Call is a newer method for parallelization. While it also uses dialog work processes for execution like the aRFC, its operational logic is quite different.

Instead of executing immediately, a bgRFC call is first saved to a persistent queue in the database. The actual processing is only triggered by an explicit COMMIT WORK statement and is managed by a dedicated scheduler. This approach makes it possible to execute tasks with an "Exactly Once" or even an "Exactly Once in Order" guarantee, which provides a high degree of reliability.

The implementation is nearly identical to that of an aRFC. The key difference is the use of the IN BACKGROUND UNIT statement, which groups one or more function calls into a single, logical unit of work.

CALL FUNCTION '<function_module_name>'
IN BACKGROUND UNIT <unit_object>.

You can find more information about this technology here:

  • SAP Support: bgRFC
  • SAP Help Portal: bgRFC (Background Remote Function Call)

 

Background Processes

Using dedicated Background Processes is another established method for achieving parallelism in SAP Systems, especially suitable for long-running and resource-intensive tasks that can be clearly divided.

Parallelizing with background processes follows the same core principle as with aRFCs: multiple tasks are started to run simultaneously. This can be achieved in two main ways. The first approach is done purely through configuration. Here, an administrator can manually schedule the same ABAP program multiple times, where each parallel job uses a unique variant with a different dataset.

The second approach is to implement this parallelization within a single ABAP program. This is done using a set of function modules that control the job lifecycle:

  • JOB_OPEN creates a new job.
  • JOB_SUBMIT adds the program and its variant as a step.
  • JOB_CLOSE releases the job to the system for execution.

For more details on implementing parallel background jobs, check out these resources:

  • SAP Community (2025): Parallel Processing with Background Jobs in SAP
  • SAP Help Portal: Programming with the Background Processing System (BC-CCM-BTC)
  • SAP Community (2014): Parallel processing of background jobs in SAP 

 

Frameworks for Easier Implementation

While the core technologies provide the fundamental mechanisms for parallel processing, implementing them directly requires handling details like load balancing, package creation and managing parallel tasks. To simplify this process, SAP provides several frameworks that build on these technologies. These frameworks offer a structured, reusable and often easier way to implement robust parallel processing.

To select the most suitable framework, the following decision matrix based on the Qualitative Weight and Summ (QWS) method provides a visual comparison. The darker the green shade, the better a framework fulfills a specific criterion. Please note that this matrix reflects my subjective evaluation for a specific use case. Your assessment will likely differ based on your project's unique requirements.

Evaluation Criteria Explained

Here is a brief summary of each criterion used in the matrix:

  • Platform Compatibility: Runs on both SAP ECC and S/4HANA systems.
  • Timeout Robustness: Handles long-running tasks without timing out.
  • Package Creation: Automatically divides data into work packages.
  • Configurable Package Size: Allows the developer to define the size of work packages.
  • Parallel Execution: Automatically starts and manages the execution of parallel tasks.
  • Result Aggregation: Helps collect and consolidate results from parallel tasks.
  • Multi-Server Function: Can distribute tasks across multiple application servers.
  • Processing Server Selection: Allows specifying a server or server group for execution.
  • Load Balancing: Automatically distributes tasks based on system load.
  • System Load Control: Allows setting limits on the maximum system resources used.
  • Implementation Effort: The complexity and time required to implement the framework.
  • Documentation Quality: The availability and quality of supporting documentation.

Now lets have a look at the individual Frameworks.

 

SPTA Framework

The SPTA Framework provides a straightforward, function-module-based approach to simplify parallel processing with aRFCs. Instead of requiring the developer to manage the aRFC calls manually, the framework encapsulates the entire parallelization logic within a single, reusable function module, SPTA_PARA_PROCESS_START_2.

To use the SPTA framework, a developer implements three specific form routines that serve as callbacks, filling them with the custom logic required for the application. The BEFORE_RFC_CALLBACK_FORM is responsible for preparing the data and creating the work packages. The core processing logic, which is to be executed in parallel, is placed within the IN_RFC_CALLBACK_FORM. After all the parallel tasks have been completed, the AFTER_RFC_CALLBACK_FORM is called to consolidate the results and make them available for further processing.

For more information on the SPTA Framework, see these resources:

  • SAP for Me (2020): 3002940 - Parallel Processing FAQ
  • [Non SAP] SAPYARD (2018): SPTA Parallel Processing Framework in ABAP
  • [Non SAP] LinkedIn (2024): Let‚Äôs Talk About the SPTA Framework: Your Guide to Parallel Processing in SAP

 

SHDB Framework

The SHDB Framework is a more powerful and modern, object-oriented framework that also simplifies the use of aRFCs. It is structured into four main components that work together to provide a robust parallelization environment: the Package Provider, the Resource Provider, the Parallelizer and the Dispatcher.

The Package Provider is responsible for automatically dividing the total dataset into smaller, processable packages according to configurable rules. The Resource Provider actively monitors the system's memory and process utilization to determine the maximum allowed number of parallel tasks, thereby preventing system overloads. The Parallelizer then calls the application-specific logic for each package in a separate aRFC task, while the Dispatcher coordinates the entire process by requesting packages and resources and launching the asynchronous tasks.

Implementation is done in an object-oriented manner, starting with the factory class CL_SHDB_PFW_FACTORY and using configuration objects from CL_SHDB_PFW_CONFIG to define parameters like the number of parallel processes or package parameters.

While a complete guide for the SHDB Framework is not publicly available at this time, some information can be found on the SAP for Me portal. Relevant resources are available there using the search terms "SHDB Framework" or "SHDB PFW".

 

CL_ABAP_PARALLEL

The CL_ABAP_PARALLEL framework is another object-oriented solution for aRFC-based parallelization. Its name, while not official, comes from its original project folder. It is a lightweight solution centered around a main class and an interface that developers use to structure their parallel logic.

The implementation pattern requires the developer to create a processing class that implements the IF_ABAP_PARALLEL interface. All the custom logic intended to run in parallel is then placed within its DO method. Finally, the entire process is managed by an instance of the main CL_ABAP_PARALLEL class and the parallel execution is triggered by calling the RUN_INST method.

For more information on CL_ABAP_PARALLEL, see these resources:

  • Book: Schwarzmann, W. (2022): Parallel Processing with ABAP Objects: Implementation and Testing, isbn: 978-1-4932-2354-1
  • SAP Help Portal: Parallel Processing
  • SAP Community (2023): Using class CL_ABAP_PARALLEL for mass parallel dialog work processes

 

Background Processing Framework (bgPF)

The Background Processing Framework serves as the dedicated framework for the bgRFC technology.

The implementation pattern requires a developer to encapsulate the business logic in a dedicated class that implements a framework interface. For most use cases, IF_BGMC_OP_SINGLE is used to ensure the process follows strict transactional rules for data consistency.

Once this class with the business logic is ready, it is passed to the CL_BGMC_PROCESS_FACTORY. This is a helper class provided by the framework that constructs the main process object for the background task. The task is then registered by calling the save_for_execution() method and the entire process is finally triggered by a COMMIT WORK statement.

For more information on the bgPF, see these resources:

  • SAP Help Protal: Background Processing Framework
  • SAP Community (2023): Introducing the Background Processing Framework

 

Parallel Processing Framework (PPF)

The Parallel Processing Framework, sometimes also referred to as the Framework for Parallel Processing (FPP), is a framework based on background processes used to structure and execute mass-data processing runs in parallel.

Its implementation requires both settings in Customizing and the development of custom ABAP function modules. A developer first defines an application type using transaction BANK_CUS_PPC. This application type links specific processing steps, such as data packaging or execution, to the custom-developed function modules that contain the business logic.

The entire process is then initiated from a report by calling the central function module BANK_MAP_PP_START, which uses the application type's configuration to manage the parallel jobs.

For more information on the PPF, see these resources:

  • SAP Community (2015): Exploring Mass run program based on PPF
  • SAP Help Portal: Parallel Processing (FPP)

 

Mass Data Framework

The Mass Data Framework is a comprehensive solution for structuring and controlling complex projects that involve large-scale data changes and is often used in migration scenarios.

The implementation requires just like the Parallel Processing Framework a combination of Customizing and development. In Customizing (via transaction SM30), a developer defines the entire project structure. This involves creating a Project Type (FINSV_MPROJ_TYP), which consists of a sequence of Activities (FINSV_MASSF_SET). Each activity is made up of one or more Steps (FINSV_MASSF_STEP), where the custom ABAP logic is assigned.

The developer's main task is to create an application class that contains the business logic for a step. This class must implement the interface IF_FINS_MASS_DATA, which includes three key methods. The GET_PACKAGES method is called to define the work packages. The PREPARE method can be used for any setup tasks before the parallel processing starts. Finally, the PROCESS method contains the core logic that is executed in parallel for each individual package.

As it is an older framework, further resources for the Mass Data Framework are primarily located on internal SAP platforms and are not publicly available.

 

I hope you found this overview informative and that it helps you tackle your own performance tuning challenges.

A special thanks to @ManuS  for the help and guidance!

entry.title: Re: RFQ Comparison
entry.content:
Good day @Dinesh_158 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Compare Supplier Quotations & Custom Analytical Queries  for more details.

To summarise, in S4HC, the compare supplier quotations app supports a maximum of three quotations at a time. This is intended to keep the comparison screen clearer, readable and to enable performance. At the moment, the app cannot be extended to handle more than the intended quantity simultaneously.

If your business process requires comparing more than three quotations at the same time, you may consider some alternatives:

  • Make use of the app in groups
  • You can use the analytical apps like Monitor Supplier Quotations which allows you to filter and export your data for broader comparison.
  • You can build a custom analytical report via CDS views and Custom Analytical Queries to display all relevant quotations side by side in Excel or SAC.

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Get & Stay Secure in the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Security Chapter
entry.content:
When moving to the public cloud with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP is taking care of many security relates topics as cloud provider. However, in order to stay secure, customers are still responsible for the mitigation of risks such as business or technical users having critical authorizations.

Here, the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report in SAP for Me comes into play as it gives you insights into security risks in the chapter "Security (Public Cloud)". This chapter gives you insights and alerts you on the following topics:

  • Identity and Access Management - get additional information and resources on how to use Identity and Access Management (IAM) to establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements
  • Deprecated Business Catalogs - revise deprecated business catalogs still in use that might be removed in future releases
  • Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles - get alerted when business users have many business roles assigned, deviating from the best practice of only one per business user
  • Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR - check for usage of this role resulting in segregation of duties (SoD) conflicts as it is intended only for the initial configuration of a system
  • Use of Read/Write Unrestricted - be alerted on business roles having unrestricted write, read and value help access
  • Business Catalog Assignments - be warned about critical assignments of business catalogs to your business users
  • Communication (Inbound/Outbound) - find customer managed communication arrangements without certificate-based authentication using only basic authentication
  • Upcoming Certificate Expiration - early warning for certificates managed by the customer that will expire within the next 90 days

You can find more details on each of these chapters below or by directly accessing the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report* for your systems in SAP for Me. 

* an authorized users is needed to access this applicaion, refer to this SAP Support page on how to get access.

 

Identity and Access Management

Identity and Access Management (IAM) ensures that all business users within an organization have defined and managed business roles. With IAM, organizations can establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements. There are several relevant applications available for managing IAM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

The SAP EarlyWatch Alert provides an overview of relevant information and resources to enable the effective use of IAM.

 

Deprecated Business Catalogs

It is important to adapt existing Business Catalogs and Business Roles resulting from the addition of new scope items or a release upgrade. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Business Catalogs are periodically revised. Some Business Catalogs will be deprecated and replaced by new ones. The deprecated Business Catalogs in the system may be removed by SAP at the time of a release after it has been declared as deprecated, so it is important to review the deprecated Business Catalogs after each release along with new scope items and make the necessary changes as soon as possible.

In this chapter, a list of deprecated business catalogs in use in the system and information how to handle this is provided.

 

Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles

SAP best practice is to assign only one business role to a business user. Each business role must represent a workplace and business roles should be created from scratch using the workplace approach.  For production, it is strongly recommended to build production roles manually to ensure compliance with external and internal compliance rules for access.

In the this chapter, the system is checked for users that have multiple business roles assigned.

 

Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

The role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is predefined by SAP and is intended only for the initial configuration of a system. Usage of this role in production does not correspond to SAP recommendations and may lead to compliance issues.

The system is checked for the usage of this role in this chapter to alert on the potential risk that comes along with using it.

 

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted

Using unrestricted fields in the maintenance of business roles allow users to have global data access, SAP best practices recommend to carefully review which users need to have restricted data access and maintain the access appropriately, e.g. ensuring employees only have access to data belonging to their sales organization.

This chapter informs about the number of busines roles with unrestricted write, read or value help access.

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted Result Table Example

 

Business Catalog Assignments

Business catalogs contain a bundle of privileges needed for accessing an app or features that are then assigned to users via business roles. This section checks for selected critical business catalogs and their assignment to business roles and users and rates this according to the valuationrules from SAP Note 863362. In case any critical business catalogs are assigned, additional details are presented as sub-chapters.

Business Catalog Assignments Overview Table Example

 

Communication (Inbound/Outbound)

It is recommended that certificate-based communication is used for technical users involved in inbound/outbound communication when possible. Usually, it is easier to detect if a certificate is compromised than detect if a password has been compromised. This chapter identifies whether any customer managed communication arrangements do not use certificate-based authenticate and provides a list of them.

 

Upcoming Certificate Expiration

In case there are any certificates where their expiration date is coming up in the next 90 days, they will be listed in this chapter to notify about this early on.

 

 

Do you want to learn more on how to find and use the security relevant content in the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Workspace? Then check out this blog for more information.

Stay tuned for more content regarding Security in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition systems to be added to the SAP EarlyWatch Alert! üöÄ

entry.title: Inside Track Philly [NSQ] September 2025
entry.content:
I was fortunate to attend the SIT NSQ day on Friday, despite a late start and traffic delays. I had indicated I was tentative since it's a bit of a drive, and home life/chores may prioritize over travel. We finally got to the parking garage around 3 pm, leaving only time for the last session.

Apologies to @RichHeilman  and @thomas_jung  and other speakers for missing their sessions. The AI demo was interesting, and applicable outside the SAP ecosystem even to my volunteer work with Scouts, as I shared with @josh_bentley  after the sessions ended.

But this story is about "getting in." I had marked my attendance as tentative even up to the time we were leaving. When my partner and I got to the front desk, I got the stonewall of "name not on list" like Studio 54 back in the day. There was no attendees list, and when they asked me to call my host, I thought, wow, I don't have many Community member phone numbers anymore. I looked at my email and found @StephanieMarley . Meanwhile, a staffer begrudgingly went to find us an escort after I pointed at the event details on the large screen behind them.

I appreciate the security, no doubt. And I have no complaints about the staff (who probably make well under half the average salary at NSQ). Then the user experience challenge gauntlet was thrown as we tried to get badged. The screen entry was bad. Super bad. Keys were super tiny on a touchscreen, latency was sluggish, and any number of times we got kicked back to start over.

Stephanie found her name in the matrix finally, and got our badges printed. I had typo'd my own name due to the horrible keying experience (I'm now Jamee), and I have no idea what my partners name (with am apostrophe) ended up as.

Whether the sign in app verified my email or not, I am unclear, as I was fortunate to key that in correctly. I was very tempted to use the example.com domain to obscure myself. But I thought I didn't need to vandalize the workflow, it was already damaged enough.

Then the imagery step loomed.  Stand up straight, comb your hair, wipe that smirk off your face, and click the shutter icon. The delay time from click to snap was interminable, leaving too long and my attention wandered. The lighting was abysmal with harsh glare and the face ending up in shadow (yet the goatee was well-lit).

You can see the results below after the app mailed me our info and images. I hope I kept the frustration off my expression!

Kudos to @GoLaSalle for explaining the inside track roster hurdles and welcoming me back into the fold!

My Mug

entry.title: Handling API Rate Limit (HTTP 429) Responses in an iFlow using the HTTP receiver adapter
entry.content:
APIs commonly return HTTP 429 (Too Many Requests) when callers exceed rate limits. Historically, handling 429 in SAP iFlows required custom logic (parsing response headers, adding waits or persistence), which introduced complexity around timing and memory management. With the latest HTTP receiver adapter update, you can handle transient 429 responses using configurable retry parameters ‚Äî reducing custom code and improving reliability.

What is a rate limits in terms of APIs?
Rate limits control how many API calls are allowed per time window, e.g., per second, per minute, per hour, or per day. Limits vary by API and by account. When limits are exceeded, APIs commonly respond with HTTP 429.

These rate limits have their own advantages and disadvantages. We would not be going into the details of these in this blog. We will discuss only on how to handle the error when we get status code 429 in an iflow using HTTP receiver adapter.

Steps to configure the HTTP receiver adapter

  1. Retry Failed Request ‚Äî enable this option.
  2. HTTP Error Response Codes ‚Äî add the error codes you want the adapter to retry (e.g., 429 for rate-limiting).
  3. Retry Interval (seconds) ‚Äî time between retry attempts. Adjust per API and expected recovery time.
  4. Retry Iterations ‚Äî number of retry attempts. Balance success probability, total wait time, and resource usage.

Suggested example configuration (starter values and to be configured as per your scenarios requirements)

  • HTTP Error Response Codes: 429
  • Retry Interval: 10 seconds
  • Retry Iterations: 5
    Estimated total (fixed-interval) wait: 10s √ó 5 = 50s (modify if Retry-After or backoff is applied).

 

Enabling retries in the HTTP receiver adapter enables the adapter to re-attempt failed requests per the configured interval and iterations. If retries succeed the iFlow continues; if retries are exhausted the message will fail unless handled by additional iFlow error handling.

For more details on HTTP Receiver Adapter please refer to the documentation : sap-cloud-integration/http-receiver-adapter

entry.title: Re: ACR ‚Äì Business Partner Email Recipient Not Pulled in...
entry.content:
Hello @MischiefMaiden 

ACR ‚Äì BP email not pulled for statutory report distribution (Public Cloud)

Root cause (most common): OPD is not resolving a TO address for the Statutory Reporting ruleset, so output falls back to Print.

Checklist to fix

OPD scope: In Output Parameter Determination, set Show Rules for to be equal to Statutory Reporting, not Billing/eDocument

Channel: Ensure the email is specified for your report, such as PH_WHT_BIR2307 and the company code.

Receiver: Use the Business Partner vendor/payee role. Don‚Äôt switch to T1 (tax authority) if you anticipate the vendor‚Äôs email.

Email Recipient: Set 'To' to the default application email, the option labelled 'BP email'. Keep CC/BCC as specified direct addresses if necessary.

In Manage Business Partner, ensure a valid email address is entered in the standard address, with a valid-from date on or before the run date. Optionally, set Preferred Communication to Email.

Re-run and verify: In Run Statutory Reports, open the Output Item. If it still displays No email recipient maintained, go back and review steps 2‚Äì4.

Switching the Receiver to T1 targets the tax authority, so the vendor‚Äôs BP email won‚Äôt populate; removing the application default email line in Email Recipient also leaves the TO blank, which might be the reason it failed earlier.

SAP Key helpful documentation

Output Parameter Determination (OPD) ‚Äì overview of rules (Channel, Receiver, Email Recipient, Email Settings). SAP Help Portal-Output Parameter Determination

Please set the Show Rules to Statutory Reporting before updating the OPD for statutory reporting. This helps ensure everything is correctly configured.  SAP Help Portal

Run Statutory Reports ‚Äì app used to generate and review output items (check why output fell back to Print). SAP Help Portal

Enable BP email for correspondence ‚Äì how to maintain a valid email on the Business Partner so applications can pull it. SAP Help Portal-Enabling E-Mail Recipients and E-Mail Channel for Business Partner Correspondence

Troubleshooting (email not received)

KBA 3537381 ‚Äì Email functionality in Run Statutory Report behaviour, prerequisites. SAP Support Portal-3537381 - Email Functionality in Run Statutory Report

KBA 2767106 ‚Äì No email recipient has been maintained (check OPD ‚Üí Email Recipient; then BP email). SAP Support Portal-2767106 - Message "No email recipient has been maintained" for billing outputs

KBA 3274509 ‚Äì Emails do not reach recipients (when output item shows Completed but mail is not received; DKIM, monitoring). SAP Support Portal

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: How to Track Data Changes in RAP with a Change Logs in RAP.
entry.content:
Hi,

A change log table alone can be used to track data modifications without storing full historical snapshots. The main table contains the active business data, while the change log table records only the metadata of each change, such as the key fields of the affected record, change type (insert, update, delete), user, and optionally the reason for change. 

 During the RAP save sequence, determinations in the behavior implementation capture these details before the transaction is committed and insert them into the change log table. This approach provides a lightweight audit trail that allows you to track when and by whom changes were made, making it suitable for compliance monitoring, reporting, and troubleshooting, while avoiding the storage overhead of a shadow table that keeps the full data history. 

Here we see some major key Advantages. 

  • Lower Storage Requirements ‚Äì Since it stores only metadata (keys, change type, timestamp, user, etc.) instead of full data snapshots, it uses significantly less database space than a shadow table. 
  • Better Performance ‚Äì Writing smaller log entries reduces the impact on transaction performance compared to saving entire records. 
  • Simplified Design ‚Äì Only one additional table is needed, making the data model and maintenance simpler. 
  • Faster Reporting on Changes ‚Äì The log contains concise, relevant details, making it easier to query and generate audit reports. 
  • Regulatory Compliance ‚Äì Still fulfills many compliance and audit requirements by showing who changed what and when. 

Steps to achieving  the Track Change Log in RAP. 

I have create 2 database tables  

  1. For basic details 
  1. Capturing the changes record table 

table 2.

Step2. 

We have to create root view  on top of the database table. 

Step 3. 

for the basic data definition we have create on metadata extension for front end display. 

@Metadata.layer:#CORE 

annotate entity zgiri_i_empl_details 

with  

{ 

@UI.facet: [  

{  

id: 'object', 

label: 'Basic Data', 

type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE, 

purpose: #STANDARD, 

position: 10 }] 

 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'Id' , position: 10 }] 

@UI.identification: [{ label: 'Id' , position: 10 }] 

Id; 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'Name' , position: 20 }] 

@UI.identification: [{ label: 'Name' , position: 20 }] 

Name; 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'Department' , position: 30 }] 

@UI.identification : [{ label: 'Department' , position: 30 }] 

 

Department; 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'CurrKey' , position: 40 }] 

@UI.identification : [{ label: 'CurrKey' , position: 40 }] 

CurrKey; 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'Salary' , position: 50 }] 

@UI.identification : [{ label: 'Salary' , position: 50 }] 

Salary; 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'CreatedBy' , position: 60 }] 

CreatedBy; 

 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'CreatedAt' , position: 70 }] 

CreatedAt; 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'ChangedBy' , position: 80 }] 

ChangedBy; 

@UI.lineItem: [{ label: 'ChangedAt' , position: 90 }] 

ChangedAt; 

}

 

 

Step 4. 

On top of the basic view we have to behavior definition. 

managed implementation in class zbp_giri_i_empl_details unique; 

strict ( 2 ); 

 

define behavior for zgiri_i_empl_details //alias <alias_name> 

persistent table zgiri_t_emp_det 

lock master 

with additional save 

authorization master ( instance ) 

early numbering 

//etag master <field_name> 

{ 

create ( authorization : global ); 

update; 

delete; 

field ( readonly ) Id; 

mapping for zgiri_t_emp_det 

{ 

ChangedAt = changed_at; 

ChangedBy = changed_by; 

CreatedAt = created_at; 

CreatedBy = created_by; 

CurrKey = curr_key; 

Department = department; 

Id = id; 

Name = name; 

Salary = salary; 

} 

}

On top the consumption view i have create behavior definition for consumption view. 

projection; 

strict ( 2 ); 

define behavior for zgiri_c_empl //alias <alias_name> 

{ 

use create; 

use update; 

use delete; 

}

Step 5. 

On top the behavior definition we have to create service definition. 

@EndUserText.label: 'service definition' 

define service Zgiri_rap_scn_ser { 

expose zgiri_i_empl_details; 

}

Step 6. 

On top the service definition we have to create  service binding. 

Step 6. 

I'm implementing logic in this class. 

CLASS lsc_zgiri_i_empl_details DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_saver. 

PROTECTED SECTION. 

METHODS save_modified REDEFINITION. 

ENDCLASS.  

CLASS lsc_zgiri_i_empl_details IMPLEMENTATION. 

METHOD save_modified. 

DATA lt_log TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zgiri_t_ch_logs1. 

DATA lt_log1 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zgiri_t_ch_logs1. 

IF update-zgiri_i_empl_details iS NOT INITIAL. 

lt_log = CORRESPONDING #( update-zgiri_i_empl_details ). 

LOOP AT update-zgiri_i_empl_details ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_log_update>). 

ASSIGN lt_log[ id = <ls_log_update>-Id ] TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_log_u>) . 

* / NAME UPDATE......................................... 

if <ls_log_update>-%control-Name = if_abap_behv=>mk-on. 

<ls_log_u>-name = <ls_log_update>-Name. 

TRY. 

<ls_log_u>-id = cl_system_uuid=>create_uuid_x16_static( ). 

CATCH cx_uuid_error. 

"handle exception 

ENDTRY. 

APPEND <ls_log_u> TO lt_log1. 
ENDIF. 
ENDLOOP. 
INSERT zgiri_t_ch_logs1 FROM TABLE _log1. 

ENDIF. 
ENDMETHOD. 

ENDCLASS. 

CLASS lhc_zgiri_i_empl_details DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler. 

PUBLIC SECTION. 
PRIVATE SECTION. 
METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION 

IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR zgiri_i_empl_details RESULT result. 

METHODS get_global_authorizations FOR GLOBAL AUTHORIZATION 

IMPORTING REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR zgiri_i_empl_details RESULT result. 

METHODS earlynumbering_create FOR NUMBERING 

IMPORTING entities FOR CREATE zgiri_i_empl_details. 
ENDCLASS. 

CLASS lhc_zgiri_i_empl_details IMPLEMENTATION. 
METHOD get_instance_authorizations. 

ENDMETHOD. 
METHOD get_global_authorizations. 

ENDMETHOD. 
METHOD earlynumbering_create. 
DATA(lt_entities) = entities. 
DELETE lt_entities WHERE Id IS NOT INITIAL. 

TRY. 

cl_numberrange_runtime=>number_get( 

EXPORTING 

nr_range_nr = '01' 

object = '/DMO/TRV_M' 

quantity = CONV #( lines( lt_entities ) ) 

IMPORTING 

number = DATA(lv_latest_num) 

returncode = DATA(lv_code) 

returned_quantity = DATA(lv_qty) 

). 

CATCH cx_nr_object_not_found. 

CATCH cx_number_ranges INTO DATA(lo_error). 
LOOP AT lt_entities INTO DATA(ls_entities). 

APPEND VALUE #( %cid = ls_entities-%cid 

%key = ls_entities-%key ) 

TO failed-zgiri_i_empl_details. 

APPEND VALUE #( %cid = ls_entities-%cid 

%key = ls_entities-%key 

%msg = lo_error ) 

TO reported-zgiri_i_empl_details. 

ENDLOOP. 

EXIT. 

ENDTRY. 

ASSERT lv_qty = lines( lt_entities ). 

* DATA: lt_travel_tech_m TYPE TABLE FOR MAPPED EARLY yi_travel_tech_m, 

* ls_travel_tech_m LIKE LINE OF lt_travel_tech_m. 

DATA(lv_curr_num) = lv_latest_num - lv_qty. 

LOOP AT lt_entities INTO ls_entities. 

lv_curr_num = lv_curr_num + 1. 
APPEND VALUE #( %cid = ls_entities-%cid 

ID = lv_curr_num ) 

TO mapped-zgiri_i_empl_details. 

ENDLOOP. 

ENDMETHOD. 

ENDCLASS.

 

output

 

 

Im going to update the this value. 

 

Here the updated value  we can see. 

And we see in the changes log table. 

conclusion

In conclusion, using a dedicated change log table provides an efficient and practical way to track data modifications without the heavy storage cost of maintaining full historical snapshots. By recording only essential metadata such as key fields, change type, user, and timestamps, it creates a lightweight yet reliable audit trail. Combined with RAP determinations during the save sequence, this approach ensures that all changes are captured before commit, enabling transparency, compliance monitoring, and easier troubleshooting. Overall, it strikes the right balance between auditability and performance, making it a smart choice for scenarios where full data history is unnecessary.
