entry.title: Foreign entity in RAP
entry.content:
Description: 

 A RAP BO entity which is not part of the BO composition tree for which it is defined. Defining a foreign entity in the behavior definition enables cross-BO message mapping between the two BOs. 

Key Concepts: 
RAP foreign entity is a component of the BC-ESI-RAP RESTful ABAP Programming Model. It is a representation of an external entity, such as a web service, that can be used in an ABAP program. The foreign entity is defined in the ABAP program and can be used to access data from the external source. 

Tips & Tricks: 
When defining a RAP foreign entity, it is important to ensure that all authentication information is correct. This will ensure that requests are sent securely and that responses are received correctly. Additionally, it is important to ensure that the URL of the external source is correct, as this will ensure that requests are sent to the correct location. 

How to use it: 
To use a RAP foreign entity, first define the entity in the ABAP program. This includes specifying the URL of the external source, as well as any authentication information that may be required. Once the entity is defined, it can be used to access data from the external source. This can be done using the RAP API, which provides methods for making requests and receiving responses from the external source. 

Example :   

"In our system, we have two distinct business entities: Inventory and Sales Order. Although they are separate, they are fundamentally linked. We manage this connection by using the product ID as the key identifier. This ensures that every time a sales order is created, the system automatically checks and deducts the correct quantity from the available stock in the inventory. This process maintains accurate, real-time stock levels, which is critical for our operations." 

@EndUserText.label : 'inverty table' 
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE 
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT 
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A 
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED 
define table zscn_t_inventory { 

key product_id : abap.char(10) not null; 
stock_level : abap.int4; 
product_name : abap.char(40); 
create_at : timestampl; 
last_chdate : timestampl; 

} 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'INTERFACE VIEW INVERNTORY' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
define root view entity ZSCN_i_INVENTORY as select from zscn_t_inventory 
{ 
key product_id as ProductId, 
stock_level as StockLevel, 
product_name as ProductName, 
create_at as CreateAt, 
last_chdate as LastChdate 
} 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'INVENTORY CONSUMPATION VIEW' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@VDM.viewType: #TRANSACTIONAL 
define root view entity ZSCN_C_INVENTORY 
provider contract transactional_query 
as projection on ZSCN_i_INVENTORY 
{ 
@UI.facet: [{ type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE }] 

@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10 , label: 'Product Id' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 10 , label: 'Product Id' }] 
key ProductId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20 , label: 'Stock Level' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 20 , label: 'Stock Level' }] 
StockLevel, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30 , label: 'Product Name' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 30 , label: 'Product Name' }] 
ProductName, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true 
CreateAt, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true 
LastChdate 
} 
managed implementation in class zbp_scn_i_inventory unique; 
strict ( 2 ); 
with draft; 

define behavior for ZSCN_i_INVENTORY //alias <alias_name> 
persistent table zscn_t_inventory 
lock master 
total etag LastChdate 
draft table zscn_t_invent_d 
authorization master ( instance ) 
late numbering 
//etag master <field_name> 
{ 
create ( authorization : global ); 
update; 
delete; 
field ( readonly ) ProductId; 

validation vali_Stock on save { create; update; } 

draft action Activate optimized ; 
draft action Discard ; 
draft action Edit ; 
draft action Resume ; 
draft determine action Prepare ; 

mapping for zscn_t_inventory { 
CreateAt = create_at ; 
LastChdate = last_chdate ; 
ProductId = product_id ; 
ProductName = product_name ; 
StockLevel = stock_level; 
} 
}

In our system, a key validation for inventory is to prevent the stock level from ever going into a negative value. 

METHOD vali_Stock.
    
LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(lv_key).

      READ ENTITY IN LOCAL MODE ZSCN_i_INVENTORY
       ALL FIELDS WITH VALUE #( (  %key = lv_key-%key ) )
      RESULT DATA(lt_result).

      CHECK lt_result IS NOT INITIAL.

      LOOP AT lt_result INTO DATA(lv_result).
        IF lv_result-StockLevel < 0 .
          APPEND VALUE #(  %tky = lv_result-%tky  ) TO failed-zscn_i_inventory.

          APPEND VALUE #(  %tky = lv_result-%tky
                 %msg = new_message_with_text( severity =
                 if_abap_behv_message=>severity-error
                 text = 'Stock value should not be negative value ' && ' ' && lv_result-StockLevel )
                 %element-stocklevel = if_abap_behv=>mk-on  ) TO reported-zscn_i_inventory .

        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

Sales order Entity  

 

@EndUserText.label : 'SALES ORDER' 
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_ANY 
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT 
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A 
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED 
define table zscn_dt_salesord { 

key sales_order_id : abap.numc(10) not null; 
product_id : abap.char(10) not null; 
quantity : abap.numc(5); 
customer_id : abap.char(10); 
order_date : abap.dats; 
@Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zscn_dt_salesord.currency' 
total_amount : abap.curr(13,2); 
currency : abap.cuky; 
create_at : timestamp; 
last_changed : timestamp; 

} 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'SALESORD CONSUMPATION VIEW' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: false 
define root view entity ZSCN_C_SALESORD 
provider contract transactional_query 
as projection on ZSCN_I_SALESORD 
{ 
@UI.facet: [{ type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE }] 

@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10 , label: 'Sales Order Id' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 10 , label: 'Sales Order Id' }] 
key SalesOrderId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20 , label: 'Product Id' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 20 , label: 'Product Id' }] 
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ 
entity: { name: 'ZSCN_C_INVENTORY', element: 'ProductId' } }] 
ProductId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30 , label: 'Quantity' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 30 , label: 'Quantity' }] 
Quantity, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40 , label: 'Customer Id' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 40 , label: 'Customer Id' }] 
CustomerId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50 , label: 'Order Date' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 50 , label: 'Order Date' }] 
OrderDate, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 60 , label: 'Total Amount' }] 
@UI.identification:[{ position: 60 , label: 'Total Amount' }] 
TotalAmount, 
Currency, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true 
CreateAt, 
@Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true 
LastChanged 

} 
managed implementation in class zbp_scn_i_salesord unique; 
strict ( 2 ); 
with draft; 

//foreign entity Zscn_i_inventory alias _inventory ; 
define behavior for ZSCN_I_SALESORD //alias <alias_name> 
persistent table zscn_dt_salesord 
lock master 
total etag LastChanged 
draft table zscn_dt_salord_d 
authorization master ( instance ) 
early numbering 
//etag master <field_name> 
{ 

create ( authorization : global ); 
update; 
delete; 
field ( readonly ) SalesOrderId; 

validation valid_ProductId on save { create; update; } 
determination stock_upadte on save { field Quantity; } 
 
draft action Activate optimized ; 
draft action Discard ; 
draft action Edit ; 
draft action Resume ; 
draft determine action Prepare ; 

mapping for zscn_dt_salesord 
{ 
CreateAt = create_at; 
Currency = currency; 
CustomerId = customer_id; 
LastChanged = last_changed; 
OrderDate = order_date;
ProductId = product_id; 
SalesOrderId = sales_order_id; 
Quantity = quantity; 
TotalAmount = total_amount; 

} 
}

without the foreign entity Zscn_i_inventory syntax ,  behavior definition of the ZSCN_I_SALESORD it only holding the structure of ZSCN_I_SALESORD it doesn't hold the structure Zscn_i_inventory .

Due to the separate entity definitions, errors from an inventory stock update cannot be directly propagated to the sales order user interface. In Failed and Reported structure will be miss match.

To propagate this we use of foreign entity syntax .

uncomment the //foreign entity Zscn_i_inventory alias _inventory ;  in Behavior definition of Zscn_i_salesord .

After adding the Foreign entity Zscn_i_inventory  alies _inventory ;  

We can see the change in the entity Zscn_i_salesord structure .

  

 

Using the Determination we are update the stock of the inventory table based on the Product id in Behavior definition implementation class . 

A critical validation has been implemented: when a sales order is created, if the requested quantity is greater than the available stock level, an error is raised in the inventory business logic. This error is then propagated to the sales order entity, making it visible on the sales order screen. 

 

METHOD stock_upadte. 

LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(lv_key). 

READ ENTITY IN LOCAL MODE zscn_i_salesord ALL FIELDS WITH 
VALUE #( ( %key = lv_key-%key ) ) 
RESULT DATA(lt_result). 

CHECK lt_result IS NOT INITIAL. 

LOOP AT lt_result INTO DATA(lv_result). 
 
READ ENTITY ZSCN_i_INVENTORY 
ALL FIELDS WITH VALUE #( ( ProductId = lv_result-ProductId ) ) 
RESULT DATA(lt_result_inventory). 

LOOP AT lt_result_inventory INTO DATA(lv_inventory). 

 DATA(lv_stock) = CONV i( lv_inventory-StockLevel - lv_result-Quantity ). 

MODIFY ENTITY ZSCN_i_INVENTORY UPDATE FIELDS ( StockLevel ) 
WITH VALUE #( ( %key-ProductId = lv_inventory-%key-ProductId 
StockLevel = lv_stock ) ) REPORTED DATA(ltreported). 

if ltreported is not INITIAL. 
 
DATA: lt_dummy LIKE reported-_inventory. 
lt_dummy = CORRESPONDING #( ltreported-zscn_i_inventory ). 

APPEND LINES OF lt_dummy TO reported-_inventory.  

endif. 
      ENDLOOP. 
   ENDLOOP. 
ENDLOOP. 

ENDMETHOD.

In above code I am using CORRESPONDING #( ltreported-zscn_i_inventory ). because of while using the EML syntax the report will be early but inside the Behavior definition it will be late structure.

 

In inventory entity this are the possible product we have in that i will chose Titan watch

When creating a sales order for a Titan watch, if the requested quantity of 50 exceeds the available stock of 40, the system will prevent the transaction and display an error.

The error which is from the inventory entity by using the foreign entity concept we are propagating the error message of inventory in sales order entity. 

Related Information: 
For more information on using RAP foreign entities, please refer to the SAP Help documentation on BC-ESI-RAP RESTful ABAP Programming Model. Additionally, there are many tutorials available online which provide step-by-step instructions on how to use RAP foreign entities in an ABAP program. 

Thanks for  

What is RAP foreign entity in SAP BC-ESI-RAP? Definition & Tips 

https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_cp_index_htm/CLOUD/en-US/index.htm?file=abenbdl_foreign.htm

entry.title: Enhancing Standard BAPIs: When and How to Do It
entry.content:
Enhancing Standard BAPIs: When and How to Do It

Introduction

Business Application Programming Interfaces (BAPIs) are one of the most powerful tools in SAP, designed to enable seamless integration between SAP and external systems. In most cases, the standard BAPIs provided by SAP are sufficient to cover typical business scenarios.

However, real-world requirements often demand more. Maybe you need an extra field that isn‚Äôt delivered, or you have to add custom checks before the data is posted. That‚Äôs when enhancing a standard BAPI becomes necessary.

In this blog, we‚Äôll look at when it makes sense to enhance a BAPI and how you can do it safely without breaking SAP best practices.

When Should You Enhance a Standard BAPI?

  1. Missing Fields
    Sometimes the delivered BAPI doesn‚Äôt expose all the fields you need. For example, a custom field in the material master might not be available.
  2. Extra Validations
    You may need business-specific checks before the BAPI processes data.
  3. Custom Logic Before or After Execution
    You might want to execute additional steps either before calling the BAPI or right after it completes.
  4. Integration with External Systems
    If you‚Äôre mapping SAP data with a third-party system, additional fields or transformations may be needed.
  5. Performance Improvements
    In some cases, the standard BAPI processes more than you need. Enhancements can help you fine-tune the performance.

How to Enhance a Standard BAPI

SAP provides different ways to enhance BAPIs, depending on the extensibility options available. Let‚Äôs go through them one by one:

  1. Using BADI Enhancements (Recommended)
  • Many standard BAPIs come with Business Add-Ins (BADI) to make them extensible.
  • Steps:
    1. Check in SE18/SE19 if a BADI exists for the BAPI.
    2. Implement the BADI and add your custom logic.
    3. Activate and test.

 

Example:

METHOD if_ex_customer_add_data~check_all_data.
  IF s_kna1-kredit = '50000'.
    "Custom validation logic here
  ENDIF.
ENDMETHOD.
  1. Enhancing BAPI Structures (Appending Fields)
  • If you need extra fields, check if the BAPI‚Äôs structure allows append structures.
  • Steps:
    1. Extend the structure using SE11.
    2. Populate the new fields via a user exit or BADI.
    3. Test the enhanced BAPI thoroughly.
  1. User Exits in BAPI Processing
  • Some BAPIs offer user exits where custom code can be added.
  • Steps:
    1. Identify the exit in SMOD.
    2. Implement it using CMOD.
    3. Add your business logic.

 

Example:

INCLUDE MF02DFEX.
IF sy-tcode = 'XD01'.
  "CUSTOM LOGIC
ENDIF.
  1. Wrapper Function Modules
  • If no BADI or exit is available, create a custom wrapper around the standard BAPI.
  • Steps:
    1. Copy the BAPI into a custom function module (ZBAPI_...).
    2. Insert your logic.
    3. Use the wrapper instead of calling the standard BAPI directly.
  1. Implicit Enhancements
  • When all else fails, use implicit enhancements at predefined spots in the BAPI.
  • Steps:
    1. Create an enhancement via SE19.
    2. Insert your custom code.
    3. Activate and test.

Conclusion

Enhancing a standard BAPI is often the only way to meet specific business needs, but it must be done carefully. By sticking to SAP‚Äôs recommended approaches‚Äîsuch as BADIs, user exits, wrapper functions, and implicit enhancements‚Äîyou can deliver the required functionality without risking system stability or upgrade issues.

The key is to choose the right enhancement technique based on your scenario, test extensively, and document everything. Done right, BAPI enhancements make your system more flexible while keeping it aligned with SAP best practices.

entry.title: Re: Getting an error when changing the material of a hand...
entry.content:
Good day @VickiG1 

Thank you for your question to the Community.

Have a look at Replicating Product Master Data & Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release ‚Äì What‚Äôs New for more details.

To summarise, in S4HC, the error message about the Material Status Design & Plan in plant during HU product change is often caused by the warehouse product status and not the plant-level material status.

Please note that when you use the Change Product or Batch function in Warehouse Monitor, the system will check whether the product is fully released for warehouse logistics execution. If the product is still in Design & Plan status in the warehouse product master or not extended to the relevant warehouse, then the posting change cannot be executed.

Consider doing the following to pinpoint where the error stems from:

  1. Make use of the Manage Product Master Data app to verify that the product you are talking about is extended to warehouse 1010 and has the right logistic status.
  2. Ensure that you have no restrictions in the warehouse lifecycle status of the material.
  3. If the product is required for operations, activate it for warehouse usage in the product master.

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Assembly Process BOM Cost and Prod Order cost doublin...
entry.content:
When you transfer the BOM to the network activity/WBS, the system calculates planned costs at the project level. These costs are based on material valuation (standard/average price).

When production orders are created and account-assigned to the WBS, they bring in their own planned costs (from the production order cost estimate). These are usually more detailed and accurate than the BOM transfer valuation.

Due to the above, the WBS now shows two sets of planned costs:

  • From the BOM transfer (valuation-based)
  • From the production orders (detailed cost estimate)

This looks like ‚Äúdouble counting.‚Äù

SAP‚Äôs recommended practice is use BOM transfer only for scheduling and component assignment (not for costing). Let production orders drive the planned costs. This way, the WBS reflects only one set of planned costs, aligned with how actuals will be posted.

entry.title: A Practical Guide to Cost Center APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with cost center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, we often encounter the need to use different APIs. Depending on the scenario, there can be several options available to integrate, replicate, or maintain cost center data.

At first glance, it may seem straightforward to simply use an API. However, the reality is more complex. cost center provides multiple API options, each designed with its own strengths, limitations, and typical use cases.

This blog post aims to bring more clarity by walking through the different API options available for cost center in the public cloud context. We will start by explaining some core concepts, such as the difference between synchronous and asynchronous APIs, and how to think about inbound and outbound APIs. Later, we will look into the individual technologies and provide guidance on how to choose the right API for your use case.

 

Synchronous vs. Asynchronous APIs

One of the most fundamental distinctions when talking about APIs is whether they are synchronous or asynchronous.

  • Synchronous APIs:
    A synchronous API works like a phone call. You ‚Äúdial‚Äù the API, send a request, and wait for the response. You know immediately whether the operation succeeded or failed. This approach is great for real-time validation, single record maintenance, and interactive applications.
  • Asynchronous APIs:
    An asynchronous API is more like sending a letter or an email. You send the request, and the system processes it in the background. The response may come later, often through a callback, message, or event. This approach is better suited for bulk operations, replication, or integrations where immediate feedback is not required.

In practice, you will often integrate APIs into workflows. A useful guideline is to stick to one type of API in your workflow. Mixing synchronous and asynchronous calls can introduce complexity, especially if you need to coordinate responses.

For example:

  • Starting with an asynchronous request and then immediately relying on a synchronous call without checking status may fail because the data is not yet processed.
  • If you must combine them, always build in the right checks: confirm the asynchronous process is complete before moving to the synchronous step.

Examples: How to work with synchronous/asynchronous APIs

  • If your process needs an instant response, such as validation or single master data change ‚Äî go for synchronous.
  • If your process deals with large volumes or can wait for processing ‚Äî asynchronous is usually more efficient.

 

Inbound vs. Outbound APIs

Another useful way of categorizing APIs is to look at whether they are inbound or outbound:

  • Inbound APIs: These are used when an external system wants to send data to an SAP S/4HANA system. In the cost center context, this could mean creating, updating, or deleting cost center master data from an external application.
  • Outbound APIs: These are used when an SAP S/4HANA system sends data or events to an external system. In other words, these APIs ‚Äúpush‚Äù information out.

 

Technologies

Working with cost center master data comes with different integration needs, and SAP offers a variety of API technologies to meet them. Each option is designed for specific scenarios and scope items, so choosing the right API depends on your particular requirements. In the sections below, we provide an overview of the key technologies available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and how they are typically used.

OData V4:

The Cost Center OData V4 service allows you to create, read, update, and delete cost center master data directly in your system. Since it is an inbound, synchronous API, it is designed for real-time interactions where you need immediate feedback on your changes. The service is built on the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP), which ensures it follows modern development principles and supports extensibility. This means you can adapt the data model and business logic to meet your specific requirements without losing compatibility during system upgrades. Typical scenarios for using this API include creating or updating cost centers from external applications or interactive user interfaces, where instant validation and confirmation are important.

üîó OData V4 cost center API on API Hub

Business Object Extensibility (Steampunk API)

For developers working on SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), the cost center business object  Steampunk APIs provide another way to interact with cost center master data. These APIs are also inbound and synchronous, making them suitable for real-time updates. 

üîóSteampunk API on API Hub

OData V2 Read APIs

In some cases, you only need read-only access to cost center data.  OData V2 Read APIs  (A2X services ) provide synchronous access to this information, enabling external systems to retrieve data in real time without modifying it. This is useful for reporting, monitoring, or any scenarios where up-to-date cost center information is required for external applications.

üîóOData V2 Read cost center API on API Hub

Business Events

When your goal is to react to changes rather than actively pull data, Business Events are the way to go. These are outbound, meaning S/4HANA pushes notifications to subscribing systems whenever a relevant change occurs. By subscribing to cost center events, a workflow or external application can respond immediately, for example by fetching updated details or triggering additional processes. This event-driven approach is particularly useful for keeping external systems in sync with S/4HANA or automating business processes based on changes in master data.

üîó Cost center Business Events on API Hub

SOAP API

As the name suggests, this API transfers the request via SOAP protocol. SOAP API CostCentreReplicationBulkRequest_In is an inbound, asynchronous API that can be used for cost center replication into your S/4HANA system. As it is based on asynchronous processing, it is suitable for changes that do not require immediate response. Usage of SOAP APIs in workflows is generally not advised, unless they perform the final operation or an operation that is not prerequisite for a follow-up step.

 üîó SOAP cost center API on API Hub 

 

How to choose an API that suits you best

While there are many scenarios where you can use cost center APIs. This little breakdown gives you an idea of which technology to use for each case. Whiie various APIs can support certain scenarios, we highlight the ones that offer the best capabilities for the given task.

 

Combining different APIs in a single workflow

Earlier, we have outlined the importance of taking caution when working with different technologies in a single workflow. This is especially true if a synchronous API and an asynchronous API coexist in the same stack. Let‚Äôs explore possible scenarios and their potential challenges.

Combining Synchronous and Asynchronous APIs

There are multiple systems that can carry out cost center changes. Each system, when the change or creation happens, sends a request to the consolidation system that collects all changes from all systems in the landscape and consolidates them. Periodically, this system returns the consolidated data to the source systems for replication and sends them also to receiver systems.

  • If this is done on a time basis, for example, the replication is triggered every midnight, there is no significance whether the replication is carried out synchronously or asynchronously.
  • But if there is a condition in place, for example when the replication is triggered after every change request, then the importance of choosing the right technology is essential.

Asynchronous APIs and Their Challenges

If you send a change request via a SOAP API (asynchronous), you would get an immediate response of HTTP status 200, which simply means that the request was accepted, not that the processing is complete. This is often confused as a response to the request being carried out, which is not exactly true. The request was only accepted and (apart from subscription to business event), there is no further notification of a successful completion. It‚Äôs important to keep in mind this distinction:

  • If you misinterpret the initial HTTP response as confirmation of successful processing and use it as a trigger for the replication, you could potentially replicate outdated data, as carrying out the change takes time and is dependent on system resources available.
  • It is also unreliable to choose an arbitrary wait time and then follow up with replication.

The only way to ensure proper synchronization is to trigger an additional GET request, verifying you have the expected data in the system. Or you can avoid this hassle by simply carrying out a synchronous request via OData API. Successful response in a synchronous API means that the request is completed in full and the data is processed and persisted. This can safely serve as a trigger condition for your further processing.

Combining APIs and Business Events

Let‚Äôs describe a different scenario where a combination of a business event and an OData API provide a more fluid and efficient integration of a simple workflow. When a cost center is changed in a system, the system implicitly triggers a business event. If there is a listener active, other system can receive this signal with a payload and act according to the desired logic. The payload only consists of the key fields, so when the system recognizes this data as necessary for further processing, it may send an OData GET request to the provider system to retrieve the full data set and persist changes.

 

Conclusion

This post provides a clear overview of the various APIs available for managing cost center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. By understanding the differences between synchronous and asynchronous APIs, inbound and outbound communication, and the specific applications of technologies like OData V4, SOAP, and Business Events, you can choose the most suitable option for your integration needs. Using the right API technology thoughtfully can simplify workflows, ensure data accuracy, and optimize system efficiency. With these insights, you are well-prepared to make the most of the capabilities each API offers while avoiding challenges in complex integrations.

entry.title: Re: Outbound delivery - unable NIl pick when not meeting MDQ
entry.content:
SAP designed the minimum delivery quantity logic to ensure that deliveries below a threshold are not processed at all. It does not distinguish between initial creation and later change. So in standard customizing, there‚Äôs no switch to say ‚Äúonly check at creation.‚Äù

One option is if you set the item category minimum delivery quantity check to A, the system will only issue a warning. At creation, users will see the warning but can still proceed. Later, in VL02N, you can reduce to zero without being blocked.

The other standard way is to use Minimum Delivery Quantity only in Sales Order. If you enforce it there, you can leave the delivery item category without the ‚ÄúB‚Äù setting. That way, the delivery can still be reduced to zero later if stock is not available.

Due to some reasons, if both the above two options is not acceptable, then, the only option is to go with custom development Try with USEREXIT_SAVE_DOCUMENT_PREPARE in MV50AFZ1 or BAdI LE_SHP_DELIVERY_PROC. In the code, you can check if the delivery is being created vs. changed (using XVBELN or change indicator) and only enforce the minimum quantity rule at creation

entry.title: Re: Maint plan operstions materials- Sap4hana public clou...
entry.content:
Good day @Egbert_de_Jong 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at Maintenance Plan, Manage Maintenance Plans & SAP Build Process Automation for more details.

To summarise, this limitation you are facing is known in S4HPC. The performance issues you see are due to the fact that every material change in a maintenance plan operation triggers full validation such as task lists, calls and object lists. That is why working manually in the Fiori app feels very slow.

In regard to mass deletion, the Maintenance Plan API allows you to create, update and delete operations but only at single record level. There is currently no delivered function that allows you to delete multiple materials in one payload. This is to prevent accidental removal of large sets of maintenance data that could disrupt scheduling.

You have the possibility to:

  • Use Api scription or BTP process automation to automate what you would manually delete one by one.
  • If you have larger volumes, you can also consider building a custom app on BTP which then consumes the API to manage maintenance plans in bulk.
  • If you occasionally do once a year clean ups, I recommend focusing on automation as this will surely save you time.

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom field enhancement for task list and order oper...
entry.content:
There are Screen Exit / Customer Subscreen in the relevant function groups:

  • Task List Operations: Function group XCN1 / SAPLCPDO (screens 3000/3100/3300 depending on detail view).
  • Order Operations: Function group SAPLCOVG (operation detail subscreens).

SAP provides customer sub screen areas in these transactions (e.g., in IW31/IW32 for orders, and in IA05/IA06/IA07 for task lists).

You can place your new field on the subscreen and bind it to the appended database field.

For Data flow, implement the corresponding function exits to move data between screen and database:

  • For task lists: EXIT_SAPLCPDO_002 / EXIT_SAPLCPDO_003 (transfer to/from your custom fields).
  • For orders: EXIT_SAPLCOIH_009 or EXIT_SAPLCOIH_010 (depending on header/operation level).

These exits are part of enhancement projects like CNEX0007 / IWO10009.

entry.title: Re: Challenges in Updating Custom Field During PO Creatio...
entry.content:
Hello @ashoktirumalasetti30 

You cannot reliably assign a value to a contract item's custom field using the PO Badi.

In S4 Public Cloud, PO BAdIs such as MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM only operate on the PO business object. The open quantity‚Äùon a contract is a standard, system-calculated value target minus released, which is updated by the contract release logic after the PO is created, not through a PO writeback to the contract.

Suggested alternative actions

Avoid creating a duplicate Open Quantity field. Use the standard open/remaining quantity from the contract release data in applications or reports.

If you need it for UI or reporting purposes, provide access via analytics using a Custom CDS View that joins contract item and release data or show the default open quantity column in Manage Purchase Contracts.

If you need to show a value during PO creation, calculate it on the PO side by comparing the contract target with the PO quantity, and display it in a custom PO field. However, avoid trying to update the contract through PO BAdIs.

Useful SAP Documentation

PO BAdIs in Public Cloud scope and limits: SAP KBA-3089559 - Use of BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_OPEN in Purchase Order

Manage Purchase Contracts app: follow-on PO creation and standard fields in the SAP Fiori Apps Library.

FAQ / Behaviour of Managing Purchase Orders: How PO Logic is Handled in the Cloud - SAP Community FAQ. SAP Community-FAQ for the Manage Purchase Orders App

Let me know if you need further assistance

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Means of Transport Ranking based on Transportation Du...
entry.content:
Dear Venkat,

It is probably because you have assigned the truck MoT for all products hence it is also valid for the material of which you have defined a specific MoT. So you should define the truck MoT only for products that can use it.

You have the help documentation for this flag:

Whether Means of Transport Valid for All Products

Indicates whether the vehicle is valid for all products. If this indicator is set, the vehicle is valid for all products for which there is a product procurement entry. If the vehicle is also assigned to other products, the attributes of the product-specific vehicle are valid. For the products for which there is no product-specific vehicle defined, the system uses the attributes of this vehicle.

If the indicator is not set, products are only valid for the vehicle if a product-specific vehicle has been defined for them.

Best regards,

Cyrille
Application Innovation Services
SAP Development Support

entry.title: Re: Dunning per Mail/Printing only if there is no Mail-Ad...
entry.content:
Hello @FabianSCC

The fact that you are still choosing Default Email Address = is initial remains the reason for the error. This setting does not function as a hard switch to force printing. Instead it still tries to resolve an email channel and fails.

  • I recommend you keep the EMAIL rule in one determination step with Defaut Email Address = is not initial.
  • Define your PRINT rule as a separate determination step without any email condition.  

This way, if an email exists then the first step triggers email. If no email exists then the first step does not apply and the second step triggers print.

This separation ensures that the system avoids trying to evaluate both rules in the same step and solves the error.

Best regards,
Chris

entry.title: Sales_Q&A - Bulgaria EUR Transition for S/4HANA Cloud Public Cloud Live Customers
entry.content:
This is only relevant for Partners and Live Customers who are required to transit Production system data with EUR adoption in Bulgaria. How To Guide Collection - Bulgaria EUR Transition for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Live Customers

In the 7th session offered by ASC Cloud ERP Expertise Services, the main topic covered is around Sales.

  • Recording - Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Sales_Q&A)
  • Presentation - Bulgaria EUR Transition for Live Customers (Sales_Q&A)  
  • Accelerator Guide - Sales Implementation Accelerator  

Key Discussion Points‚Äå

‚Äå1. Transition Overview‚Äå

  • New company code and sales organization will be created for Bulgaria‚Äôs EUR transition, effective January 2026.
  • Master data (customer, material, pricing) must be extended to the new sales org; transactional data (orders, deliveries) must be recreated.

‚Äå2. Sales Area Impact‚Äå

  • ‚ÄåMaster Data Updates‚Äå:
    • ‚ÄåCustomer/Material Master‚Äå: Extend to new sales org via Fiori apps or migration cockpit.
    • ‚ÄåPricing‚Äå: Update condition records with new sales org/currency.
    • ‚ÄåBOMs/Customer Hierarchies‚Äå: Migrate using dedicated objects (e.g., "material BOM").
  • ‚ÄåTransactional Data‚Äå:
    • ‚ÄåOrders/Quotations‚Äå: Close existing documents (set rejection reason) and recreate in new org.
    • ‚ÄåBilling Documents‚Äå: Cancel and regenerate with EUR currency.

‚Äå3. Manual Activities‚Äå

  • Output forms, tax conditions, and workflows require updates to reflect EUR currency.
  • Sales orders with billing plans/WBS elements must be manually recreated (no migration tool).

Live Questions & Answers

Topic Area‚Äå

‚ÄåQuestion‚Äå

‚ÄåAnswer

‚ÄåSales Orders with WBS‚Äå

The sales order can be in various states of delivery and invoicing.  How do you recommend handling the orders for which delivery is already created? We also have bought in and drop shipment/third party procurement scenario. So, there might be PO linked to the SO Item. How to handle sales orders in delivery/invoicing stages or with linked POs?

Reject deliveries and close orders to regenerate in new org. Linked POs must also be reversed.

‚ÄåEPPM Projects‚Äå

Migration approach for projects linked to sales orders (cost collection)?

Projects likely need extension to new sales org; consult project line experts for confirmation.

‚ÄåChecklist Request‚Äå

Can a procurement-style checklist be provided for sales?

Presenter will add a checklist slide to the session materials.

 Call-to-Action

  • Impacted partners/customers could start transition
  • Final planned session: ad-hoc sessions may follow based on feedback

Please view all content and raise questions with tag #Bulgaria
